docs.lead_paragraph: Scientists have identified a gene that is a major cause of inherited deafness among Ashkenazi Jews, a group that includes 90 percent of the six million Jewish people in the United States. The discovery does not mean that deafness is any more common in Jews than in other people. In the general population, including Jews, roughly 1 in 1,000 children is born deaf, half from hereditary deafness. The new research simply identified a particular genetic mutation that is more common among deaf Jewish people than among deaf people from other backgrounds.

headline.main: Gene Identified as Major Cause of Deafness in Ashkenazi Jews

docs.abstract: Scientists have identified gene that is major cause of inherited deafness among Ashkenazi Jews, group that includes 90 percent of six million Jewish people in US; study was conducted by scientists from National Institute on Deafness and Other Communication Disorders, Louisiana State University, Michigan State University, University of Antwerp and New York University (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Federal regulators have cited the Kings County Hospital Center in Brooklyn for serious flaws in how it decides who should receive emergency care and for treatment delays that may have jeopardized the health of some patients, according to a document released yesterday. The Federal Health Care Financing Administration warned the hospital about the problems late last month, and hospital officials said they have already taken significant steps to correct them.

headline.main: U.S. Agency Faults Hospital On Emergency Care Delays

docs.abstract: Federal regulators cite Kings County Hospital Center in Brooklyn for serious flaws in how it decides who should receive emergency care and for treatment delays that may have jeopardized health of some patients; Federal Health Care Financing Administration warned hospital about problems late last month and hospital officials say that they have already taken significant steps to correct them; union leaders and other critics say problems are symptomatic of more serious deficiencies at public hospital, which serves much of south Brooklyn and has suffered budget and staff cuts in recent years (M)
docs.snippet: Federal regulators have cited the Kings County Hospital Center in Brooklyn for serious flaws in how it decides who should receive emergency care and for treatment delays that may have jeopardized the health of some patients, according to a document...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Giuliani administration agreed yesterday to release most of the $150 million that it had withheld from nonprofit groups since July, completing a budget deal with the City Council that also eliminates a 12.5 percent surcharge on the personal income tax of New York City residents. The compromise came after a five-month standoff between Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone, who had pushed for both the release of the money for the nonprofit groups and the elimination of the surcharge. Although Mr. Giuliani had initially opposed eliminating the surcharge, he said yesterday that he had changed his mind months ago.

headline.main: In Budget Pact, Giuliani and Council Drop a Tax Surcharge

docs.abstract: NYC Mayor Giuliani administration agrees to release most of $150 million that it had withheld from nonprofit groups since July, completing budget deal with City Council that also eliminates 12.5 percent surcharge on personal income tax of New York City residents; compromise comes after 5 month standoff between Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and City Council Speaker Peter F Vallone; City Council, for its part, agrees to save $165 million it had earmarked for debt reduction, putting money into reserve fund instead; it also agrees to allot $15 million for renovations to Museum of Modern Art (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ONE of the great ironies of the nonprofit world is that it has spawned a large and lucrative for-profit industry. After all, a nonprofit has needs -- especially if it is going to reach out to all those would-be donors and wannabe philanthropists who wouldn't know a worthy cause unless they heard from one. Making a nonprofit heard is a team effort, say experts in the field. It involves real-estate agents (home is where the telephone and computers are), list makers (the better to find donors), celebrity-search agencies (for every cause, a famous face), mail and telephone fund-raising solicitors (ah, the power of the pitch), headhunters (an experienced staff can be hard to find) and more. Many more.
docs.abstract: Nonprofit world has spawned large and lucrative for-profit industry to serve its needs; sampling of some of professionals paid by nonprofits; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: HOW do two brothers who came from Queens get to mingle with Brooke Astor and other luminaries on New York society's A list? Well, first they become powerful publishing executives. Then they agree to be co-chairmen of one of the season's most sparkling benefits, the Municipal Art Society's fall gala at the renovated Grand Central Terminal. Hundreds of fund-raising benefit balls and dinners are held every fall in New York, and for every one, enlisting the right combination of celebrity, society and money -- the names that appear on the invitations that go to thousands of potential ticket buyers -- is essential for success.

headline.main: It's All in Who You Know (and Who They Know)

docs.abstract: Right combination of celebrity, society and money is key to success for hundreds of fund-raising benefit balls and dinners held every fall in New York City; people whose names on invitation help sell tickets discussed; successful benefit for Municipal Art Society cited; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A few years back, when they envisioned their retirement, John and Mary Greenan saw themselves relaxing on Cape Cod's pristine sands in the summer and viewing Vermont's glorious foliage in the fall. With wise investments and their monthly Social Security checks, the Greenans, of this Westchester city, were able to indulge their passion for travel. In addition to Cape Cod and Vermont, there were trips to Florida, Maryland, Montauk, Virginia and the Outer Banks of North Carolina.

headline.main: Scrambling For Coverage; Medicare H.M.O. Cutbacks Strand Thousands of Clients

docs.abstract: Article on estimated 440,00 Medicare beneficiaries throughout country whose coverage is being canceled by HMO's being forced to scramble for new, more expensive coverage; some people have decided to spend several thousand dollars more on supplemental insurance to fill gaps in traditional Medicare; others are searching for health maintenance organizations that are taking new clients while others will fall back on basic Medicare coverage; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: On a weekday afternoon in 1992, Sunny Cloud, an insurance saleswoman and single mother in Marietta, Ga., dropped by her home unexpectedly and found her 16-year-old son, Ron, smoking marijuana. Stunned, Ms. Cloud hustled the boy off to the nearest hospital emergency room, where she asked doctors to screen his urine. ''I was scared,'' she said recently, ''and I didn't know what else to do.''
docs.abstract: Growing number of companies are marketing test kits with which they say parents can learn if their children are smoking marijuana or taking illicit; they can cite the steady rise in illicit teen-age drug use over past six years and offer their products as lifelines for parents struggling to keep their teen-agers away from drugs; critics warn that tests will turn parents into detectives, undermining the fragile trust essential in guiding children through teen-age years; say worried parents should be talking with their children instead of relying on tests that can produce false results; graph; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: If Anthony Mazzocchi's vision becomes reality, the United States will someday have a Labor Party that rivals Britain's. Mr. Mazzocchi said he hoped the new Labor Party would fill the void that he, and the 1,200 delegates gathered here for the party's constitutional convention, see in American politics.

headline.main: Labor Party Gets to Work At Its Second Convention

docs.abstract: Labor Party's constitutional convention draws 1,200 delegates to Pittsburgh; Anthony Mazzocchi, driving force behind fledgling party, expresses hope that it will fill void that he sees in American politics; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In Pennsylvania Station, labor organizers have undertaken one of the biggest efforts in the nation to unionize fast-food workers. Their goal is to unionize a total of 120 workers at 10 fast-food outlets on the Long Island Rail Road level -- including Dunkin' Donuts, Nathan's and Roy Rogers -- that are all run by a single franchisee, the Riese Organization.

headline.main: A Drive to Unionize Fast-Food Workers

docs.abstract: Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees Union seeks to unionize total of 120 workers at 10 fast-food outlets on Long Island Rail Road level of Pennsylvania Station in New York City; all outlets are operated by Riese Organization, which is currently involved in contract dispute with union involving workers at other restaurants in city; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: At one time, Barclays Bank here was losing 36 of its 1,600 employees a year, 10 times the death rate at most American companies. At the private Minbank Clinic, where the senior managers of Zambia's biggest mining houses, banks and industrial companies are treated, about half of all appointments are AIDS-related.
docs.abstract: Special report, Dead Zones, on effects of Africa's AIDS epidemic on continents already shaky economies; epidemic is robbing Africa of much of its potential, striking first at educated its urban professionals, who are backbone of economic expansion; damage is immeasurable since it appears in ways that cannot be seen--namely, businesses that will never be founded, ideas that will never be advanced and university departments that will never be created; in eastern and southern Africa where epidemic is worst, infection rates vary between 10 and 25 percent and virtually all will die within 10 years; photos; charts; map; graph (L)
